name: Chloe Bernstein
clarity_response: An app that gives you 3-5 curated things to do in NYC based on your preferences, schedule, and budget — instead of making you search through hundreds of options.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
what_feels_off: The three example cards feel slightly random together — art gallery, jazz bar, nature walk. It works but feels like it's trying to prove range rather than cohesion. Real shortlists would probably be more internally consistent.
objections: Still no launch date. 'Early access opens soon' is the same vagueness as V1's waitlist, just rebranded. When is soon? What does 'small group already getting shortlists' mean — 5 people? 50?
gut_reaction: This is more concrete than V1. The three-card example actually shows me what the shortlist looks like. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: When does it actually launch? Is this an app or website? Can I share the shortlist with my group chat?
price_reaction: Freemium sounds right. Would pay $5-8/month if the recs are actually good.

name: Aaliyah Johnson
clarity_response: A curated shortlist of 3-5 NYC events matched to your interests and filters, so you don't have to scroll through platforms.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
what_feels_off: The new hero is less punchy than V1. 'Stop ending up at the same place again' is slightly better for rut people but I did relate to the scrolling-six-apps line. This feels like it traded one strength for another.
objections: No mention of group planning. I plan for 6 people. Does the shortlist work for a group? Can I share it?
gut_reaction: Good. The three example cards help a lot. I understand the product better now.
unanswered_questions: Group features? Can I share the shortlist? Launch date?
price_reaction: Would pay something reasonable.

name: Mei-Lin Wu
clarity_response: A filtered event recommendation app for NYC that surfaces 3-5 quality things to do based on your interests, timing, and budget.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
what_feels_off: Social proof section still feels light. Interview quotes describe a problem, not the product experience. I want to hear from someone who actually used it.
objections: I plan things for myself and others. The page is very individual-experience focused. No mention of groups or sharing.
gut_reaction: Stronger than V1. The example shortlist is the best addition — I can actually see what I'd receive.
unanswered_questions: Is there a web version or app only? What happens after I sign up for early access?
price_reaction: Happy to pay if it works. ClassPass model would make sense.

name: Omar Farouk
clarity_response: NYC weekend activity recommender that gives you a short, filtered list instead of overwhelming you with options.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The 'small group already getting shortlists' line is vague. How small? Is this a real beta or are they just saying that?
objections: As the group chat organizer, I need to know: can I share these shortlists? That's my use case. If I find something good, I send it to the group. Is that possible?
gut_reaction: I'm in. The three example cards actually showed me the product. That was missing in V1.
unanswered_questions: Sharing features? Launch timeline? What neighborhoods are covered?
price_reaction: Freemium or low monthly. Would not pay more than $10/month.

name: Tamika Harris
clarity_response: An app that cuts through NYC event overload and gives you a curated shortlist of 3-5 things that actually match what you like.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
what_feels_off: Nothing major. The copy is tighter than V1. The objection about 'gets sharper' is still a bit thin — I want to understand the personalization mechanism better.
objections: How does personalization actually work after initial setup? The copy is vague on this.
gut_reaction: This speaks to me more than almost any app I've seen. Would sign up immediately.
unanswered_questions: Personalization mechanism, launch date, newsletter frequency.
price_reaction: Would pay up to $10/month.

name: Keiko Yamamoto
clarity_response: A personalized shortlist of NYC events and activities based on your interests and availability, with 3-5 recommendations per session.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
what_feels_off: The example shortlist has a jazz bar, art gallery, and park walk — nothing explicitly couple-friendly or date-night oriented. As someone looking for date activities, this doesn't quite signal that it works for that use case.
objections: Date ideas and couple activities aren't mentioned. Is this product built for solo use or groups/couples too?
gut_reaction: Good product. The framing is cleaner than V1. Would sign up but with moderate excitement.
unanswered_questions: Date-night / couple use case? Group features? What app platform?
price_reaction: Fair. Would pay $5-10/month.

name: Liam O'Brien
clarity_response: A curated NYC event finder that replaces the multi-platform research spiral with a short, personalized shortlist.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The hero headline change actually cost something. V1's 'scrolling six apps' was more visceral. This headline is accurate but softer.
objections: I want to see real beta testimonials. The social proof section is still all interview quotes — nobody who's actually used the product.
gut_reaction: Better than V1 in structure, slightly weaker in hero impact. Still would sign up.
unanswered_questions: When does early access open exactly? What's the waitlist queue like?
price_reaction: Freemium is right. Would pay for premium if recs are accurate.

name: Jenna Liu
clarity_response: An event shortlisting app for NYC that filters based on your interests, schedule, and budget and sends you 3-5 curated picks.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
what_feels_off: The early access framing feels slightly overhyped. 'A small group of New Yorkers is already getting shortlists' — is this true? It reads like manufactured social proof.
objections: Still need a launch date. Early access with no timeline isn't that different from a waitlist.
gut_reaction: Solid. Three example cards made the product tangible. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Actual launch date, group features, iOS vs Android.
price_reaction: Freemium works. Would pay $6-8/month.

name: Ethan Nakamura
clarity_response: A curated shortlist tool for NYC events — you set filters once, get 5 quality recommendations, skip the 200-result scroll.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
what_feels_off: The behavior change objection handler is new and good, but it feels slightly out of place among the other objections. It's more philosophical. Might work better near the top.
objections: No mention of neighborhoods — is this Manhattan-only? The Washington Heights card is a good signal but I need more assurance it covers my area (Bushwick).
gut_reaction: This works for me. Clearer product story than V1.
unanswered_questions: Borough coverage, launch date, sharing features.
price_reaction: Free to start, pay for premium if it works.

name: Lucia Ferraro
clarity_response: A personalized NYC event recommendation tool that replaces research overwhelm with a short, actionable shortlist.
strongest_line: Your weekend shouldn't take longer to plan than to enjoy.
what_feels_off: As an event coordinator, I notice the example cards don't show any group-friendly or large venue events. This feels very solo or couple-focused. For group planning, I need to know this works.
objections: Group planning use case is invisible. I'm the one coordinating 8 people — can I share the shortlist? Can multiple people take the quiz?
gut_reaction: Love the concept. The three example cards are a huge improvement. Would sign up right now.
unanswered_questions: Group features? Sharing? Multi-user?
price_reaction: Would pay $10-15/month if group features exist.

name: Theo Papadopoulos
clarity_response: An NYC event curation tool — pick your interests and constraints, get 3-5 recommendations worth your time.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
what_feels_off: The new behavior-change objection feels slightly AI-generated — too clean, too logical. Real people don't talk about 'removal' as a concept. The language is smart but slightly corporate.
objections: Still vague on launch. 'Early access' without a date is just a rebrand of 'waitlist.'
gut_reaction: Strong product pitch. Would click the CTA.
unanswered_questions: Launch date, neighborhoods, pricing model.
price_reaction: Freemium. Would pay for accuracy.

name: Danielle Brooks
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist app — you filter by interest, budget, location and get 3-5 solid recommendations instead of hundreds of options.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The couple / date use case is completely invisible. I'm actively looking for couple activities and the copy doesn't speak to that at all. The example cards include a jazz bar which could be date-adjacent but it's not framed that way.
objections: No date-night or couple framing. Is this product built for solo users or does it work for two people?
gut_reaction: Good. I'd sign up. I just wish the couple use case were acknowledged.
unanswered_questions: Couple/date use case, actual launch date, is there a newsletter option?
price_reaction: Would pay. ClassPass pricing model would make sense.

name: Elena Petrov
clarity_response: An NYC event app that sends you a short curated list of things to do based on your interests instead of a wall of options.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The behavior change objection is good but buried. 'Making something different the easier choice' — that's exactly my problem and it's in a Q&A section nobody reads.
objections: My crew decides things via group text. Does this integrate with that? Can I send a shortlist to my group?
gut_reaction: Oh this actually gets it. The headline speaks to me specifically — I literally end up at the same place every weekend.
unanswered_questions: Group sharing, launch timing, does it cover Harlem?
price_reaction: Would pay something small. Not more than $8/month.

name: Amira Khalil
clarity_response: A personalized shortlist of NYC activities — you set your preferences, get 5 recommendations you'd actually want to do.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: As a spin instructor, I have irregular hours and my 'this weekend' is Tuesday and Wednesday. The page frames everything around the traditional weekend. Not sure if it accounts for non-standard schedules.
objections: Does 'when are you free' mean literally any day, or is this weekend-only?
gut_reaction: Way more relatable than V1. The hero speaks to me directly instead of assuming I have a research problem.
unanswered_questions: Non-standard schedule support? Coverage of outer Brooklyn?
price_reaction: Fair. Would pay.

name: Darius Jackson
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist that takes your interests and filters and gives you 3-5 recommendations worth doing.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The example jazz bar recommendation — Nublu in East Village — wouldn't feel relevant if I'm in Flatbush. The proximity framing ('0.4 mi away') is great but makes me wonder how accurate it is for outer-borough users.
objections: Will this work for someone in Flatbush who doesn't want to go to Manhattan? The examples all feel Manhattan-centric.
gut_reaction: Yes. The hero finally speaks to me instead of the 'I have 12 apps' person. I'm in.
unanswered_questions: Outer borough coverage, launch date.
price_reaction: Would pay $5-10/month. More if it's good.

name: Natasha Ivanova
clarity_response: An app that replaces the research spiral for NYC weekend activities with a personalized 3-5 item shortlist.
strongest_line: Making 'something different' the easier choice.
what_feels_off: The social proof still feels weak. I want to hear from someone who actually tried this and found something unexpected.
objections: The 'small group already getting shortlists' claim feels unverifiable. Is this real beta testers or is that a marketing line?
gut_reaction: This is exactly what I need. Saturday morning I have energy to do something new. By 2pm I'm back at brunch. This product understands me.
unanswered_questions: Launch date, is there a newsletter option, neighborhood coverage.
price_reaction: Would pay. Freemium or low monthly.

name: Marcus Thompson
clarity_response: A curated shortlist of NYC events and activities filtered by your interests and schedule — 3-5 picks instead of hundreds of results.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: As a bartender, I follow LES nightlife closely. The example Jazz bar (Nublu) I know — that's a solid venue but it's not niche. If this surfaces stuff even I don't know, that's impressive. If it's just curated Eventbrite, it's not.
objections: Is the curation actually discovering things I don't already know about, or is it just filtering existing listings? That's the whole value question and the page doesn't answer it clearly.
gut_reaction: The concept is right. I'm slightly skeptical the execution is as differentiated as promised.
unanswered_questions: What's the actual curation mechanism? Is this AI or human editors?
price_reaction: Free to try. Would pay if it showed me things I genuinely didn't know.

name: Morgan Reilly
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist app — set your preferences, get 3-5 things actually worth doing, no research spiral.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: I'm trying to shift to daytime activities and the example shortlist includes a 9pm jazz residency. The default seems to be evening/nightlife. Daytime and outdoor activities need more visibility.
objections: Daytime / morning activities don't seem to be prominent. The examples all skew evening. Does this work for people who want to do things Saturday morning?
gut_reaction: Good. The hero actually speaks to my situation. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Daytime event coverage, launch date, any app preview?
price_reaction: Would pay. Comparable to a streaming service.

name: Yusuf Abdi
clarity_response: A filtered NYC activity shortlist — you tell it your preferences, it gives you 3-5 options instead of 200.
strongest_line: Three filters. Five recommendations. Zero rabbit holes.
what_feels_off: I'm a restaurant manager — I actually know a lot of what's happening in the city already. This feels built for people who don't know where to start. I'm not that person.
objections: I already know most of what's out there in my area. The value proposition — cutting through noise — doesn't apply to me the same way. I need genuine discovery, not better filtering.
gut_reaction: Not really for me. I already know what's happening. I need something that surfaces things I genuinely don't know about.
unanswered_questions: Is the curation actually discovering unknown things or filtering known ones?
price_reaction: Only if it showed me genuinely new things.

name: Gabrielle Moreau
clarity_response: An NYC weekend activity shortlist — filtered to your interests, budget, and schedule — so you stop defaulting to the same places.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The group planning angle is still missing. I organize for friend groups constantly. 'Share your shortlist via text' from V1 recommendations is not in V2. That was a miss.
objections: Can I share the shortlist? I'm the social connector. If I can't send this to my group chat, it loses half its value.
gut_reaction: Love it. This is finally a product that gets the real problem. I'd sign up immediately.
unanswered_questions: Sharing / group features, launch date, outer Brooklyn coverage.
price_reaction: Would pay $8-12/month.

name: Fatima Al-Hassan
clarity_response: A personalized NYC event curation tool that gives you a short, filtered shortlist instead of making you research everything yourself.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: I'm recently single and the copy doesn't speak to my situation at all — meeting new people, solo-friendly activities, things where it's okay to show up alone. The whole framing is 'your group' or 'your weekend.'
objections: Solo-friendly and 'good for meeting people' use cases aren't addressed. As a recently single person this matters.
gut_reaction: Decent. The hero speaks to me. But I want the product to feel relevant to where I am in life right now.
unanswered_questions: Solo-friendly options? Events where you can meet people? Social aspect?
price_reaction: Would pay something reasonable.

name: Aisha Rahman
clarity_response: NYC activity shortlist app — 3-5 filtered recommendations based on your interests instead of a scroll-through-everything experience.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: Nothing major. The page is better than V1 for me specifically. The hero finally names my actual situation.
objections: Minor: still no launch date. But I'd sign up anyway.
gut_reaction: Yes. This gets me. 'Cool stuff I never hear about until it's over' — that's my whole life. I'd sign up immediately.
unanswered_questions: Launch date, neighborhood coverage, notification settings.
price_reaction: Would pay. Freemium with premium tier.

name: Jake Rosenberg
clarity_response: A curated shortlist of NYC things to do — filters handle the research, you get 3-5 solid options.
strongest_line: Making 'something different' the easier choice.
what_feels_off: I've lived in NYC 4+ years and I know Park Slope cold. The product needs to surface things outside my default neighborhood. The page doesn't address this — will it push me geographically?
objections: Will it actively expand my geographic range or just optimize within my comfort zone? I need the former.
gut_reaction: Good concept. Needs to prove it goes beyond the obvious.
unanswered_questions: Geographic discovery vs optimization? Cross-borough options?
price_reaction: Free trial. Would pay if it works.

name: Renée Dubois
clarity_response: An NYC weekend activity recommender that gives you 3-5 filtered, curated options so you don't end up at the same place again.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The Washington Heights example card is good for me specifically. But the jazz bar example (East Village) is far from Washington Heights. If I set my distance filter, would I actually get uptown stuff?
objections: Will this surface things near Washington Heights and Inwood? Or is it Manhattan-below-110th-Street-focused?
gut_reaction: The Washington Heights park example actually made me feel seen. I want this to be real.
unanswered_questions: Uptown coverage, launch date, is this an app?
price_reaction: Would pay a small amount. Under $10/month.

name: Andre Williams
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist — you set your interests and filters, get 3-5 recommendations without having to scroll through hundreds of options.
strongest_line: No social media profile required. No influencer feed.
what_feels_off: The transparency question still isn't really answered. 'We track what you pick, skip, and save' — okay but that's just behavioral tracking. How does that translate into quality recommendations? The gap between input and output is still a black box.
objections: The mechanism is still opaque. 'Gets sharper' via tracking behavior is vague. I'd want to understand the curation better before trusting it.
gut_reaction: Better than V1. The 'no social media profile' line still resonates. The transparency is slightly better but still not enough for me to fully commit.
unanswered_questions: How does curation actually work? What's the data model? Is there human editorial involvement?
price_reaction: Would pay for quality. Skeptical until I see evidence of quality.

name: Kira Johansson
clarity_response: An event recommendation app for NYC that gives you a short, filtered list based on your preferences — not an algorithm that feeds you what's trending.
strongest_line: No social media profile. No influencer feed. No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: The 'including quiet, solo-friendly, and low-key options' line in step 1 reads like it was added for people like me but it still feels like an afterthought. It's tucked into a list item, not surfaced prominently.
objections: Is the quiet/solo-friendly framing real or just a checkbox they added? I need to see it reflected in examples or categories more prominently.
gut_reaction: Warmer to this than V1. The solo-friendly callout, however small, made me feel less like I was the weird edge case.
unanswered_questions: What does the solo/quiet category actually look like? How prominent is it in the product?
price_reaction: Would pay if quality is real.

name: Adrienne Cole
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity shortlist that replaces multi-platform research with 3-5 filtered recommendations.
strongest_line: No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: As a UX researcher I notice this copy makes a lot of promises without any substantiation. 'We filter for quality' — what does quality mean? Who defines it? 'Gets sharper over time' — sharper how? These are functional claims that need evidence.
objections: Functional claims need evidence. 'We filter for quality' is a promise, not a feature. What's the quality bar? Who decides?
gut_reaction: Better than V1. The no-account line helps. But I'm still skeptical of unsubstantiated quality claims.
unanswered_questions: What does quality mean in practice? Human curation or algorithmic?
price_reaction: Would pay only after seeing the product work.

name: Olivia Santos
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist — you pick your filters, get 3-5 quality picks, skip the research.
strongest_line: No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: I research everything before going. '3-5 recommendations' sounds great but I still want to vet each one before committing. The page doesn't say how much detail I get per recommendation. The example card is helpful — I'd want that level of detail plus more.
objections: How much information do I get per recommendation? The example card shows category + location + timing + match reason. Is that it? Or can I drill in?
gut_reaction: Appealing to me. Low-pressure, low-key, no social media involvement. I might actually try this.
unanswered_questions: Detail level per card, launch date, is there a preview mode.
price_reaction: Would pay if quality checks out.

name: Tara Patel
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist app — no social media, no account required, just preferences and 3-5 quality recommendations.
strongest_line: No social media profile required. No influencer feed. No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: The 'We're actively building' language slightly undermines trust for me. I've deleted Instagram. I don't sign up for things that aren't ready. The early access framing is slightly concerning.
objections: Is this actually live or still in development? I don't want to give my email to something that might not launch.
gut_reaction: The no-account, no-social-media framing is exactly right for me. I'd consider signing up.
unanswered_questions: Is this live now? When does early access start? What newsletter is replacing this?
price_reaction: Would pay for a reliable weekly shortlist.

name: Raj Patel
clarity_response: An NYC event curation app that filters results by your interests and constraints and returns 3-5 quality picks.
strongest_line: No social media profile required.
what_feels_off: The Kehinde Wiley example is well-known. The jazz venue (Nublu) is good but not obscure. The park walk is generic. None of these feel like 'things I wouldn't have found myself.' For someone with developed taste, this shortlist is not impressive.
objections: The example cards aren't proof of discovery — they're proof of curation from existing, well-known options. I need evidence of genuine novelty.
gut_reaction: Not sure this is better than what I already do. The no-social-media angle is good but the examples need to be more genuinely obscure.
unanswered_questions: How deep does the catalog go beyond well-known venues? Is there editorial involvement?
price_reaction: Only if it showed me things I genuinely didn't know.

name: Simone Baptiste
clarity_response: A low-friction NYC shortlist of 3-5 curated activities — no social media profile, no overwhelming results page, just filtered picks.
strongest_line: No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: The behavior-change objection handler is thoughtful but slightly too long. I have a private Google Maps list with 40 pins because I don't trust external tools. The copy doesn't address why I should trust this over my own system.
objections: Why should I trust this over my own curation system? The page doesn't explain what makes their quality judgment better than mine.
gut_reaction: More appealing than V1. The no-account line is important to me. Still skeptical but would maybe try it.
unanswered_questions: How is curation quality defined? What's the editorial process?
price_reaction: Would try free tier. Would pay if quality is demonstrably better than my own research.

name: Jamal Carter
clarity_response: A curated event shortlist for NYC — you filter by interest and schedule, get 3-5 picks, skip the research overhead.
strongest_line: No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: The shortlist shows three cards that feel somewhat aligned — art, music, outdoors. But they're all different neighborhood distances. Would a real shortlist be geographically coherent? The jazz bar is 0.4mi away but from where? The park is in Washington Heights — that's a 45-min trip from Cobble Hill.
objections: Geographic coherence of the shortlist: would I actually get recommendations near me, or a mix of neighborhoods?
gut_reaction: Good. I prefer 1-2 great things over 5 mediocre ones, and this promises exactly that. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Geographic logic of shortlist, quality threshold, what 'matched' means.
price_reaction: Would pay. Prefer under $10/month.

name: Diana Tran
clarity_response: An NYC activity shortlist app that replaces scrolling with 3-5 filtered, quality recommendations based on your preferences.
strongest_line: No social media profile required. No influencer feed. No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: I only trust 3 friends for recommendations. This product is asking me to trust an algorithm I can't see. The 'no account required' is good but doesn't tell me why their judgment is better than my trusted network.
objections: Trust in an unknown system is the issue. I trust people, not apps. What makes this reliable?
gut_reaction: The anti-algorithm framing is right. But I need some proof of quality — a testimonial, an editorial note, something — before I trust it.
unanswered_questions: Who curates? Is there human involvement? What's the quality bar?
price_reaction: Would pay if I trusted it. First need to trust it.

name: Nina Aleksandrov
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist that filters by your interests and budget, surfacing 3-5 quality recommendations instead of a wall of results.
strongest_line: No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: Looking for low-key date activities with my partner — the copy doesn't speak to that use case. The solo-friendly callout is there but the couple/date context is missing entirely.
objections: Date-night use case isn't addressed. Is this primarily solo or does it suggest couple-friendly activities?
gut_reaction: Good. I like the low-key, no-fuss positioning. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Couple-friendly filter? Date activity recommendations? Launch date?
price_reaction: Would pay for accurate, quiet recommendations.

name: Ben Shapiro-Stein
clarity_response: A filtered NYC activity shortlist — you set preferences, get 3-5 curated picks without social media influence.
strongest_line: No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: The mental load of vetting this product itself is starting to feel like the problem I'm trying to escape. The copy is better but the 'early access' and 'we're actively building' makes me feel like I'm signing up for something incomplete.
objections: Early-stage product risk. I deleted Instagram to reduce low-quality signal. Signing up for an unfinished app is more low-quality signal.
gut_reaction: Conceptually right. Practically too early for me. I'll wait until it's real.
unanswered_questions: When will this be fully operational? What does early access mean in practice?
price_reaction: Would pay if ready. Not ready to pay for a beta.

name: Sade Adeyemi
clarity_response: An NYC event curation tool — set your interests and filters, get a short, quality shortlist instead of researching everything yourself.
strongest_line: No social media profile required. No influencer feed.
what_feels_off: The example museum card is good but everything feels a bit young and social. I prefer quiet bars and museums, and the jazz residency example assumes I want something social. Low-key doesn't always mean solo — it means low-pressure.
objections: Low-key doesn't mean solo, it means low-pressure and unhurried. Does the product understand that distinction?
gut_reaction: Better than V1. I'd try it. The anti-algorithm framing works well for me.
unanswered_questions: What does the quiet/low-key category include in practice?
price_reaction: Would pay for a good weekly shortlist.

name: Rachel Park
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist that surfaces time-limited cultural events — pop-ups, exhibitions, limited-run shows — before they close.
strongest_line: The events you find out about the day after they end? We surface those.
what_feels_off: Three example cards is better than one. But the Kehinde Wiley example I already know about — it's a well-known gallery. I want to see an example of something genuinely obscure or insider that I wouldn't have found otherwise.
objections: The example cards prove curation but not discovery. Kehinde Wiley at Sean Kelly is mainstream. Show me a micro-gallery opening or an underground pop-up.
gut_reaction: Yes. This is built for me. The time-limited event focus, the 'before they're gone' framing — exactly my pain. I'd sign up right now.
unanswered_questions: Depth of catalog beyond well-known galleries? Any editorial curation?
price_reaction: Would pay. This is worth money if it's real.

name: Tomás Guerrero
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist focused on cultural and time-sensitive events — you don't have to discover them yourself anymore.
strongest_line: Exhibitions ending this week, sample sales, limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups.
what_feels_off: The 'Van Gogh immersive' type experiences aren't really represented. The example cards feel more traditional gallery/live music. I like immersive and experiential art. Does this cover that?
objections: Coverage of immersive art and experiential events beyond traditional galleries?
gut_reaction: Love the concept. The three-card shortlist preview is the right move. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Coverage of immersive/experiential art? Does it cover art fairs and pop-up galleries?
price_reaction: Would pay up to $15/month for this.

name: Zara Osei
clarity_response: An NYC cultural event shortlist that gives you 3-5 curated picks including time-limited, niche, and hard-to-find events.
strongest_line: Instagram is random. I want to actively search for what's happening, not wait for the algorithm.
what_feels_off: I work in a gallery. The Kehinde Wiley example is too mainstream for someone like me. And the 'ending this week' urgency angle, while correct, sometimes triggers anxiety over genuine excitement. I want discovery, not FOMO.
objections: The catalog needs to include things even gallery-adjacent people don't already know. Kehinde Wiley at Sean Kelly is not that.
gut_reaction: Right product for me, mostly right copy. The three-card shortlist helps. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Depth of catalog, editorial curation vs algorithmic, focus on under-the-radar events.
price_reaction: Would pay. I spend money on culture.

name: Esme Blackwell
clarity_response: An intentional event discovery tool for NYC — 3-5 curated cultural picks based on your interests, not a feed of everything happening.
strongest_line: The events you find out about the day after they end? We surface those.
what_feels_off: Time Out NYC failed me because it was too broad. I need to believe this is actually different — that the curation is based on taste and quality, not just popularity. The example cards don't fully prove that.
objections: What is the actual quality bar? 'We filter for quality' isn't specific enough. Are there human curators? Editorial standards?
gut_reaction: Appealing. I want to be the person who knows about the pop-up first. This product promises that. I'd try it.
unanswered_questions: Editorial vs algorithmic curation, what 'quality' means in practice.
price_reaction: Would pay for high-quality curation.

name: Nikolai Volkov
clarity_response: A shortlist of 3-5 cultural events in NYC curated around your interests — time-limited, niche, things worth knowing before they end.
strongest_line: Exhibitions ending this week, sample sales, limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups.
what_feels_off: I want to see an example of a true pop-up that wouldn't appear in Time Out or Eventbrite. The three examples feel safe — established gallery, established venue, public parks. Nothing I couldn't find with a basic Google search.
objections: The examples don't prove differentiation from existing platforms. Show me something I couldn't find elsewhere.
gut_reaction: This is exactly what I want from a product. Would sign up immediately. Just need proof the catalog is as deep as promised.
unanswered_questions: Catalog depth beyond mainstream, how they source less-known events.
price_reaction: Would pay. Culture spending is the last thing I cut.

name: Courtney Ng
clarity_response: An NYC cultural event shortlist that catches time-limited events before they close — exhibitions, pop-ups, limited-run shows.
strongest_line: The events you find out about the day after they end? We surface those.
what_feels_off: Honestly very little. The Kehinde Wiley example is slightly mainstream but the fact that there are now THREE example cards makes the shortlist feel real. This is what I needed to see in V1.
objections: Minor: I missed a Kehinde Wiley show in real life and this copy uses Kehinde Wiley as the example. That's either extremely well-researched or a coincidence, but it lands for me personally.
gut_reaction: I'm signing up right now. This is exactly the product I've wanted for years.
unanswered_questions: Launch date, coverage of outer Brooklyn galleries, Instagram integration for saving.
price_reaction: Would pay. Whatever the price is, I'll pay it.

name: Sofia Reyes
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist that surfaces time-sensitive cultural events before they end — matched to your interests and schedule.
strongest_line: The events you find out about the day after they end? We surface those.
what_feels_off: As an architect, I'm interested in design events, architecture tours, open-house weekends. These aren't mentioned. The categories listed are mostly entertainment and nightlife-adjacent. Niche professional interest categories aren't covered.
objections: Professional/niche interest categories like architecture, design, and urbanism aren't mentioned. Does this cover that space?
gut_reaction: Love the concept. Three cards is a much better proof point than one. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Niche/professional interest coverage, catalog depth, launch date.
price_reaction: Would pay.

name: Samuel Obi
clarity_response: An NYC cultural event shortlist that catches time-limited events — gallery openings, pop-ups, limited-run shows — before they end.
strongest_line: Exhibitions ending this week, sample sales, limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups.
what_feels_off: I want to be the person who knows about the pop-up before everyone else. The product promises this, but the example cards include a publicly listed gallery (Sean Kelly) and a venue (Nublu) I already know. The promise of exclusivity isn't demonstrated.
objections: The example shortlist doesn't demonstrate the 'before everyone else' promise. Give me one example card for something I couldn't find with a Google search.
gut_reaction: I want this product to exist. I'd sign up. Just need the catalog to be as deep as the copy promises.
unanswered_questions: Catalog depth, sourcing of lesser-known events, launch date.
price_reaction: Would pay up to $15/month.

name: Priya Nair
clarity_response: A curated shortlist of NYC cultural events based on your interests — surfaces time-sensitive, niche, and hard-to-find events you'd otherwise miss.
strongest_line: The events you find out about the day after they end? We surface those.
what_feels_off: Photography-specific events, gallery opens, portfolio shows — not mentioned in categories. The category list reads as entertainment-focused. As a photographer this feels like it might miss my world.
objections: Photography events, gallery shows for emerging photographers, portfolio exhibitions — are these in scope?
gut_reaction: Good product concept. I follow 30+ accounts and still miss things. This could solve that. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Niche category coverage, catalog depth, launch date.
price_reaction: Would pay. Information asymmetry has real cost.

name: Ravi Krishnan
clarity_response: An NYC cultural event shortlist — curated around your interests, focused on time-limited and niche events you'd otherwise miss.
strongest_line: The events you find out about the day after they end? We surface those.
what_feels_off: The social proof section doesn't include anyone who sounds like a culture professional or sophisticated consumer. All quotes are from 20-somethings describing generic overwhelm. As a brand consultant, I want to know that culturally sophisticated users find this useful.
objections: Social proof quotes don't represent my demographic. I want to see that someone with developed taste finds this valuable.
gut_reaction: I'm in. Time Out has been useless for years. This is the product I've wanted.
unanswered_questions: Catalog depth, curation quality bar, whether there's editorial curation.
price_reaction: Would pay. Not price sensitive.

name: Paloma Cruz
clarity_response: A curated NYC shortlist of cultural events — exhibitions, pop-ups, limited-run shows — matched to your interests before they close.
strongest_line: Exhibitions ending this week, sample sales, limited-run shows, neighborhood pop-ups.
what_feels_off: As a museum educator, I actually know the event landscape well. My gap is pop-ups and temporary installations — things that don't go through official museum channels. The copy talks about this but the example cards don't prove it.
objections: The catalog needs to include unofficial and community events, not just officially listed shows.
gut_reaction: This product should exist. I'd sign up and I'd tell colleagues.
unanswered_questions: Coverage of unofficial/community events, catalog sourcing, launch date.
price_reaction: Would pay. Culture is worth it.

name: Yara Nazari
clarity_response: An intentional NYC event shortlist — curated picks for cultural and time-sensitive events, filtered to your interests, so you don't miss things before they close.
strongest_line: The events you find out about the day after they end? We surface those.
what_feels_off: The 'I want to be the person who knows about the pop-up before everyone else' positioning is real but the three example cards don't deliver on it. Give me something I couldn't find on Eventbrite.
objections: Example cards don't prove catalog depth beyond existing platforms. Needs one genuinely hard-to-find example.
gut_reaction: Good. I missed a Kehinde Wiley show last year (different venue). This product is the solution. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Catalog sourcing, coverage of film festivals and screenings, launch timeline.
price_reaction: Would pay. Film editing community shares info badly — this product would help.

name: Nkechi Okafor
clarity_response: An NYC activity shortlist app that filters for budget, interests, and location — gives you 3-5 real options including quality free events.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
what_feels_off: The under $10 tier in the text is good — but it's buried in an objection handler. It should be in the main How It Works section where the budget filter is described.
objections: Where does the app itself cost money? Is the app free? This is still not explicitly stated.
gut_reaction: YES. Finally. Someone who gets that free events in NYC are usually bad and we need curation. I'd sign up immediately.
unanswered_questions: Is the app itself free? Under $10 tier needs to be more prominent. Bushwick coverage?
price_reaction: Would use if free or low cost. Would pay $3-5/month.

name: David Kim
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist that curates quality options within your budget — including actually-good free events, not just anything that's free.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
what_feels_off: The under $10 tier is mentioned in the objection handler but not in the main filter description in How It Works. That inconsistency is confusing — which one is true?
objections: Is the under $10 tier in the How It Works step or just in the objection handler? The page contradicts itself slightly.
gut_reaction: Great. The 'free usually means not fun' line is exactly right. I would sign up.
unanswered_questions: App pricing, consistency of budget tier presentation, coverage of SoHo area.
price_reaction: Would use free tier. Would pay $3-5/month for better filtering.

name: Hannah Kim
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist filtered by your budget — surfaces quality free and low-cost activities so you don't have to guess.
strongest_line: We're building this for New York, which means we're building it for people with real budgets.
what_feels_off: The app pricing is still unaddressed. If the app costs money, I can't use it. This is a critical gap for my decision.
objections: If the app itself costs money, it's immediately out of reach for me. Is it free to use?
gut_reaction: The 'building for people with real budgets' line is the best new addition. That's the most directly inclusive thing I've ever seen in NYC app copy. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: App pricing, free tier availability, Flatbush coverage.
price_reaction: Would use if the app is free or freemium. Cannot pay for the app itself.

name: Kwame Asante
clarity_response: An NYC activity shortlist that curates events within your budget — including free, under $10, and under $20 options — so you can actually participate in city life.
strongest_line: We're building this for New York, which means we're building it for people with real budgets.
what_feels_off: The example paid card shows a $15 jazz residency. That's on the high end of what I'd consider. The under $10 tier existing is good — I just want to see a sub-$10 example card as well.
objections: Show me a sub-$10 example card, not just mention the filter exists.
gut_reaction: This finally speaks to people like me. The 'real budgets' line is honest. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: App pricing, under-$10 event examples, coverage of Prospect Heights.
price_reaction: Would use free tier. Could pay $3/month.

name: Jasmine Wright
clarity_response: A curated NYC shortlist of quality events and activities filtered by budget, interests, and distance — so you can find something worth doing without spending money you don't have.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
what_feels_off: The app pricing is still unaddressed. For someone with price sensitivity 5, this is critical. If the app costs anything, I can't use it.
objections: Is the app itself free? This is my only dealbreaker question.
gut_reaction: This is the product I've needed. The free events quality filter is exactly right. I'd sign up right now.
unanswered_questions: App pricing, is there a free tier, Williamsburg gallery coverage.
price_reaction: Cannot pay for the app itself. Need a free tier.

name: Grace Tanaka
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist app that filters for quality within your budget — including curated free events that are actually worth attending.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
what_feels_off: Eventbrite's free filter was wildly inconsistent. The copy says this is different but doesn't say how they determine quality. What's the standard?
objections: What's the quality bar for 'actually fun free events'? Who decides? Is there curation or is it automated?
gut_reaction: Good. The free events quality promise is exactly what I need. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Quality curation methodology, app pricing, Lower East Side coverage.
price_reaction: Would use free tier. Could pay $2-3/month.

name: Leo Tran
clarity_response: A curated NYC shortlist of things to do, filtered by budget including free and under-$10 options — so you can find genuinely good things without spending much.
strongest_line: We're building this for New York, which means we're building it for people with real budgets.
what_feels_off: As a freelance writer with income volatility, 'under $10' is sometimes still too much. I need things that are free. The free tier is there but I want to feel like a priority user, not someone being accommodated.
objections: The free tier feels secondary to paid tiers in how it's presented. I want free events to feel like a first-class feature, not a filter.
gut_reaction: Better than V1. The real budgets line is the best thing on this page. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Free event quality and volume, app pricing, Crown Heights coverage.
price_reaction: Need free tier. Cannot pay for app.

name: Camila Herrera
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist app that curates activities within your budget — free, under $10, under $20 — so you don't waste time on bad options or options you can't afford.
strongest_line: We're building this for New York, which means we're building it for people with real budgets.
what_feels_off: The 'free event that turned out to be a sales pitch with a cash bar' is literally my experience. The copy doesn't directly address this. 'We filter for quality' is good but doesn't explicitly call out misleading free events.
objections: Does the free filter exclude misleading events — ones that are technically free but require purchases?
gut_reaction: This speaks to me. The Long Island City example card is actually near me. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: What constitutes 'free' — are drink-minimum events filtered out? App pricing. LIC coverage.
price_reaction: Would use free or very low cost. $3-5/month max.

name: Leah Goldstein
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist filtered by budget and interests — surfaces free and affordable events that are actually good quality.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
what_feels_off: App pricing is still unclear. If this has a premium tier and the free tier gets limited recommendations, that's going to frustrate me. I need the free tier to be meaningful.
objections: What does the free tier get you vs the paid tier? If the good recs are paywalled, this isn't for me.
gut_reaction: Good. The budget positioning is better than V1. Would sign up with caution about pricing.
unanswered_questions: Free vs paid tier features, Harlem coverage, launch date.
price_reaction: Free tier must be meaningful. Would pay $3-5/month if free tier works.

name: Carlos Mendez
clarity_response: A curated event shortlist for NYC filtered by your budget — surfaces quality free, under $10, and under $20 activities.
strongest_line: We're building this for New York, which means we're building it for people with real budgets.
what_feels_off: The $15 jazz residency example card — that's my ceiling, not my sweet spot. I want a sub-$10 example. The under $10 tier is mentioned but not demonstrated.
objections: Show me an under-$10 example card. 'Free or under $10' as a filter is only convincing if the example reflects it.
gut_reaction: Better than V1. The 'real budgets' line is what I needed. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Sub-$10 event examples, Williamsburg coverage, app pricing.
price_reaction: Would use free. Could pay $2-3/month for premium.

name: Maya Chen
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist for people on real budgets — quality free and affordable picks, so you can have a social life without constantly overspending.
strongest_line: We filter for quality so 'free' doesn't mean 'not actually fun.'
what_feels_off: AmeriCorps stipend is very low. I need free, zero-cost activities consistently. The free tier framing is good but I worry the best recommendations will be behind a paywall.
objections: If quality free recommendations require a paid subscription to access, this product fails its promise to budget-conscious users.
gut_reaction: This finally makes me feel seen as someone who can't always afford things. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Free tier limitations, coverage of Williamsburg free events, launch date.
price_reaction: Need meaningful free tier. Cannot commit to paid subscription.

name: Isabel Torres
clarity_response: An NYC activity shortlist filtered by budget and interests — gives you curated options including free and under-$10 picks that are actually worth going to.
strongest_line: We're building this for New York, which means we're building it for people with real budgets.
what_feels_off: The 'free events that are actually fun' promise needs to be demonstrated, not just stated. The free example card (Fort Tryon Park) is fine but it's a park. Parks are not curated — they're just… there. A curated free event would be a community art show or a free film screening, not a nature walk.
objections: The free example card (park walk) doesn't demonstrate curation quality — parks are free by default. Show me a curated free event that required actual editorial judgment to surface.
gut_reaction: Good page. The 'real budgets' framing is the strongest change from V1. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: App pricing, what counts as a curated free event, Bushwick coverage.
price_reaction: Would use free tier. Would pay $3-5/month for premium.
